awd_titl_txt: US-Israel Collab: Pathogens and disease transmission in migratory birds along the Palearctic-African flyway
awd_abstract_narration:
The primary aim of the study is to understand the role that migratory birds play in spreading various disease causing agents around the world.  Wildlife has been implicated as a vector, capable of transmitting, or as an environmental reservoir, capable of storing, different types of viral and bacterial pathogens. In this project, the researchers will capture, tag, collect blood and parasite samples from birds belonging to ten different species that stop over in Israel to feed and rest during migration. These birds migrate between breeding sites in Europe and Asia and overwintering sites in Africa. Individual birds will be tested for exposure to avian influenza virus and Newcastle Disease virus, the presence of salmonella bacteria, lice and ticks, and their general state-of-health will be assessed. Many of the animals will be fitted with GPS tags that record the movement and locations of individuals as they migrate, breed, and overwinter over a period of many months to several years. In addition, this study will provide new methods and tools for describing and predicting disease transmission by migrating birds. These tools will be useful both for human and livestock health, as well as for the conservation and management of wildlife. They will be made available to the ecological disease research community and for educational purposes at high school and colleges.

The scientific aim of the study is to advance knowledge of how migration impacts the evolutionary ecology of hosts and pathogens within migratory host populations and also to understand this within a community of multiple species residing in an area ephemerally used by migratory populations. This will be achieved by comparing the serological, immunological and physiological state of resident and migratory subpopulations within Israel with individuals opportunistically sampled in breeding and overwinter grounds, at sites revealed by movement information obtained from GPS and data-logging tags. These individual-health data, high resolution movement data as well as pathogen genomic data, will be analyzed to assess relationships in timing, intensity and spread of diseases within and beyond Israel. Agent-based computational models will be constructed using the Nova modeling platform and used to assess relationships among correlated variables.  In addition, these models will be use to predict responses of disease systems to both land-use practices and global climate change.

por.por_cntn:
The central goal of this project was to study aspects of bird-mediated disease transmission in a multi-host resident-migratory system by gathering, analyzing, and modeling pathogen infection[PK1] , microbiome, and movement data from migrant and resident birds in the Israeli Passage of the Palearctic migratory bird flyway. Of particular interest were the presence and movement of avian influenza viruses (AIVs) and diarrheal causing Salmonella and Shigella [PK2] bacteria. 

 

In the context of AIV, our surveillance efforts revealed the presence of H4N6 for the first time in Israel in a fecal sample of a wild mallard duck, that suggest the spread of AIV subtypes from Europe/Asia to the Middle East by migratory birds. In collaboration with scientists from Ben Gurion University in Israel, we developed and applied a customized antigen microarray as a surveillance tool for AIV in wild bird populations.  Our microarray contained recombinant hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA) proteins of 15 different subtypes from 60 different influenza strains and used it to characterize the AIV immune history of mallards (Anas platyrhynchos) and steppe buzzards (Buteo buteo vulpinus) using fecal samples collected from identified individuals. Our results revealed extensive both long-term immune histories to influenza subtypes H3, H5, H7, H10, H13, N1, N4, N6, and N8, as well as a recent H5 infection in about 50% of the mallards. These results indicate that our antigen microarrays are a promising AIV surveillance tool for wild bird populations.

 

In the context of gut microbiome studies, we characterized the “core” microbiome of mallard ducks, demonstrated the utility of microbiome data for pathogen detection in barn swallows, and evaluated relationships between potential health indicators (pathogen infection, microbiome), space use, plumage coloration, and reproductive success in barn owls.  We found Salmonella in 23% of barn swallows and demonstrated in barn owls that individuals with lower blood parasite infection intensities had larger home range areas, which translates into higher reproductive success in females.  Additional barn owl, barn swallow, and common crane studies indicate that the movement ecology of hosts impacts their microbiota, and our data suggest that improved understanding of how hosts make use of their spatial landscape are needed to construct a predictive framework for conserving endangered species and anticipating diseases outbreaks, particularly AIV. 

 

Also, in the context of gut microbiome studies, we evaluated the impacts of migration on the health of individuals. Migration is one of the most physical and energetically demanding periods in an individual bird’s life. The composition of the bird’s gut or cloacal microbiota can temporarily change during migration, likely due to differences in diets, habitats and other environmental conditions experienced en route, as well as migration-induced physiological stress. We studied the latter by sampling the cloacal bacterial microbiota of steppe buzzard stopping over in Israel, after a nearly 2000 km crossing of the Saharan Desert. We found the early arriving individuals had better body condition and lower levels of the shigella bacteria Escherichia-Shigella (as well as three other genera) than later arrivals. Overall, our results indicated that variation in steppe buzzard microbiota is linked to variation in migratory patterns and body condition thereby highlighting the importance of sampling the microbiota of GPS-tracked individuals on multiple occasions along their migration routes to gain a more detailed understanding of the links between migration, cloacal microbiota, and health in birds.

 

Our movement studies of the common crane serendipitously revealed that they are the heaviest migrating birds to routinely soar on thermal updrafts while crossing the sea. Prior to our observations, which we document in the attached figure, thermal soaring conditions above the sea were assumed to be absent or too weak for terrestrial migrating birds, forcing large obligate soarers to take long detours, and facultative soarers to cross the Mediterranean and Black Seas exclusively by flapping. While atmospheric convection does develop at sea, it has been largely ignored in bird migration research. Our high-resolution biologging data, however, showed that common cranes, the heaviest facultative soarer that migrates over these seas, regularly soars during sea crossing. These crossing occurred predominantly in autumn when large water-air temperature differences followed the passage of mid-latitude cyclones and was no different than over-land soaring in mid-10 latitudes. Thus, our results indicate large soaring migrants tend to avoid sea crossing not due to absence or weakness of thermals but due to their uncertainty and the costs of prolonged flapping.
